dt: {bc}having substance {bc}involving matters of major or {d_link|practical|practical:1} importance to all concerned

dt.t: need {wi}substantive{/wi} evidence to prove her guilt

dt: {bc}belonging to the substance of a thing {bc}{sx|essential||}

dt.t: the {wi}substantive{/wi} verb is the verb {it}to be{/it}

dt: {bc}having the nature or function of a noun
{bc}relating to or having the character of a noun or {d_link|pronominal|pronominal} term in logic

quotes.t: "This was not a drive-by P.R. stunt, and I actually thought it might be," said Representative Zach Wamp, Republican of Tennessee. "It was a {qword}substantive{/qword}, in-depth discussion with our conference, and he's very effective."

The first {qword}substantive{/qword} issue that the Supreme Court considered in its Brown opinion was whether, as originally understood, the Fourteenth Amendment prohibited racial segregation in public schooling. The justices concluded that the historical record was inconclusive.

The common critique of art's pleasures and entertainments—that they are trivial, devoid of {qword}substantive{/qword} value, and degrading of art's genuine worth—rests on ignoring this diversity by making two false assumptions: first, that there is basically one kind of aesthetic pleasure in art's entertainment and, secondly, that this pleasure is always a shallow and trivial one, which distracts us from interest in art's real meaning and truth.

shortdef: having substance : involving matters of major or practical importance to all concerned
considerable in amount or numbers : substantial
real rather than apparent : firm; also : permanent, enduring

dt: {bc}a word or word group functioning syntactically as a noun

et: Middle English {it}substantif{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}sustentif{/it}, from {it}sustentif{/it}, adjective, having or expressing substance, from Late Latin {it}substantivus{/it}, from Latin {it}substantia{/it}
shortdef: noun; broadly : a word or word group functioning syntactically as a noun

dt: {bc}a right (as of life, liberty, property, or reputation) held to exist for its own sake and to constitute part of the normal legal order of society
